segment.source: The User State Migration Tool (USMT) 10.0 is designed so that an IT engineer can precisely define migrations using the USMT .xml scripting language.
segment.target: The User State Migration Tool (USMT) 10.0 is designed so that an IT engineer can precisely define migrations using the USMT .xml scripting language.

segment.source: USMT provides the following sample scripts:
segment.target: USMT provides the following sample scripts:

segment.source: Rules that use the MigXmlHelper.GenerateDocPatterns helper function, which can be used to automatically find user documents on a computer without the need to author extensive custom migration .xml files.
segment.target: Rules that use the MigXmlHelper.GenerateDocPatterns helper function, which can be used to automatically find user documents on a computer without the need to author extensive custom migration .xml files.

segment.source: Rules to migrate user profiles and user data.
segment.target: Rules to migrate user profiles and user data.

segment.source: MigUser.xml gathers everything in a user’s profile and then does a file extension- based search of most of the system for other user data.
segment.target: MigUser.xml gathers everything in a user’s profile and then does a file extension- based search of most of the system for other user data.

segment.source: If data doesn’t match either of these criteria, the data won’t be migrated.
segment.target: If data doesn’t match either of these criteria, the data won’t be migrated.

segment.source: For the most part, this file describes a "core" migration.
segment.target: For the most part, this file describes a "core" migration.

segment.source: The following data does not migrate with MigUser.xml:
segment.target: The following data does not migrate with MigUser.xml:

segment.source: Files outside the user profile that don’t match one of the file extensions in MigUser.xml.
segment.target: Files outside the user profile that don’t match one of the file extensions in MigUser.xml.

segment.source: Access control lists (ACLs) for folders outside the user profile.
segment.target: Access control lists (ACLs) for folders outside the user profile.

segment.source: This section describes the user data that USMT migrates by default, using the MigUser.xml file.
segment.target: This section describes the user data that USMT migrates by default, using the MigUser.xml file.

segment.source: It also defines how to migrate ACLs.
segment.target: It also defines how to migrate ACLs.

segment.source: When you specify the MigUser.xml file, USMT migrates everything in a user’s profiles including the following:
segment.target: When you specify the MigUser.xml file, USMT migrates everything in a user’s profiles including the following:

segment.source: My Documents, My Video, My Music, My Pictures, desktop files, Start menu, Quick Launch settings, and Favorites.
segment.target: My Documents, My Video, My Music, My Pictures, desktop files, Start menu, Quick Launch settings, and Favorites.

segment.source: Folders from the All Users and Public profiles.
segment.target: Folders from the All Users and Public profiles.

segment.source: When you specify the MigUser.xml file, USMT also migrates the following from the All Users profile in Windows® XP, or the Public profile in Windows Vista, Windows 7, or Windows 8:
segment.target: When you specify the MigUser.xml file, USMT also migrates the following from the All Users profile in Windows® XP, or the Public profile in Windows Vista, Windows 7, or Windows 8:

segment.source: When you specify the MigUser.xml file, the ScanState tool searches the fixed drives, collects and then migrates files with any of the following file extensions:
segment.target: When you specify the MigUser.xml file, the ScanState tool searches the fixed drives, collects and then migrates files with any of the following file extensions:

segment.source: The asterisk () stands for zero or more characters.
segment.target: The asterisk () stands for zero or more characters.

segment.source: USMT migrates ACLs for specified files and folders from computers running both Windows® XP and Windows Vista.
segment.target: USMT migrates ACLs for specified files and folders from computers running both Windows® XP and Windows Vista.

segment.source: For example, if you migrate a file named File1.txt that is read-only for User1 and read/write for User2, these settings will still apply on the destination computer after the migration.
segment.target: For example, if you migrate a file named File1.txt that is read-only for User1 and read/write for User2, these settings will still apply on the destination computer after the migration.

segment.source: To migrate ACLs, you must specify the directory to migrate in the MigUser.xml file.
segment.target: To migrate ACLs, you must specify the directory to migrate in the MigUser.xml file.

segment.source: Using file patterns like .doc will not migrate a directory.
segment.target: Using file patterns like .doc will not migrate a directory.

segment.source: The source ACL information is migrated only when you explicitly specify the directory.
segment.target: The source ACL information is migrated only when you explicitly specify the directory.

segment.source: USMT migrates operating-system components to a destination computer from computers running Windows 7 and Windows 8
segment.target: USMT migrates operating-system components to a destination computer from computers running Windows 7 and Windows 8

segment.source: The following components are migrated by default using the manifest files:
segment.target: The following components are migrated by default using the manifest files:

segment.source: The groups to which a user belongs can be found by right-clicking My Computer on the Start menu and then clicking Manage.
segment.target: The groups to which a user belongs can be found by right-clicking My Computer on the Start menu and then clicking Manage.

segment.source: RAS connection and phone book (.pbk) files
segment.target: RAS connection and phone book (.pbk) files

segment.source: These settings are not available for an offline migration.
segment.target: These settings are not available for an offline migration.

segment.source: For more information, see Offline Migration Reference.
segment.target: For more information, see Offline Migration Reference.

segment.source: This list may not be complete.
segment.target: This list may not be complete.

segment.source: There may be additional components that are migrated.
segment.target: There may be additional components that are migrated.

segment.source: Some settings, such as fonts, are not applied by the LoadState tool until after the destination computer has been restarted.
segment.target: Some settings, such as fonts, are not applied by the LoadState tool until after the destination computer has been restarted.

segment.source: For this reason, restart the destination computer after you run the LoadState tool.
segment.target: For this reason, restart the destination computer after you run the LoadState tool.

segment.source: Although it is not required for all applications, it is good practice to install all applications on the destination computer before restoring the user state.
segment.target: Although it is not required for all applications, it is good practice to install all applications on the destination computer before restoring the user state.

segment.source: Installing applications before migrating settings helps to ensure that the migrated settings are not overwritten by the application installers.
segment.target: Installing applications before migrating settings helps to ensure that the migrated settings are not overwritten by the application installers.

segment.source: The versions of installed applications must match on the source and destination computers.
segment.target: The versions of installed applications must match on the source and destination computers.

segment.source: USMT does not support migrating the settings of an earlier version of an application to a later version, except for Microsoft Office.
segment.target: USMT does not support migrating the settings of an earlier version of an application to a later version, except for Microsoft Office.

segment.source: USMT migrates only the settings that have been used or modified by the user.
segment.target: USMT migrates only the settings that have been used or modified by the user.

segment.source: If there is an application setting on the source computer that was not touched by the user, the setting may not migrate.
segment.target: If there is an application setting on the source computer that was not touched by the user, the setting may not migrate.

segment.source: When you specify the MigApp.xml file, USMT migrates the settings for the following applications:
segment.target: When you specify the MigApp.xml file, USMT migrates the settings for the following applications:

segment.source: The following is a list of the settings that USMT does not migrate.
segment.target: The following is a list of the settings that USMT does not migrate.

segment.source: If you are having a problem that is not listed here, see Common Issues.
segment.target: If you are having a problem that is not listed here, see Common Issues.

segment.source: USMT does not migrate the following application settings:
segment.target: USMT does not migrate the following application settings:

segment.source: Settings from earlier versions of an application.
segment.target: Settings from earlier versions of an application.

segment.source: The versions of each application must match on the source and destination computers.
segment.target: The versions of each application must match on the source and destination computers.

segment.source: USMT does not support migrating the settings of an earlier version of an application to a later version, except for Microsoft Office.
segment.target: USMT does not support migrating the settings of an earlier version of an application to a later version, except for Microsoft Office.

segment.source: USMT can migrate from an earlier version of Microsoft Office to a later version.
segment.target: USMT can migrate from an earlier version of Microsoft Office to a later version.

segment.source: Application settings and some operating-system settings when a local account is created.
segment.target: Application settings and some operating-system settings when a local account is created.

segment.source: For example, if you run /lac to create a local account on the destination computer, USMT will migrate the user data, but only some of the operating-system settings, such as wallpaper and screensaver settings, and no application settings will migrate.
segment.target: For example, if you run /lac to create a local account on the destination computer, USMT will migrate the user data, but only some of the operating-system settings, such as wallpaper and screensaver settings, and no application settings will migrate.

segment.source: Microsoft Project settings, when migrating from Office 2003 to Office 2007 system.
segment.target: Microsoft Project settings, when migrating from Office 2003 to Office 2007 system.

segment.source: ICQ Pro settings, if ICQ Pro is installed in a different location on the destination computer.
segment.target: ICQ Pro settings, if ICQ Pro is installed in a different location on the destination computer.

segment.source: To successfully migrate the settings of ICQ Pro, you must install ICQ Pro in the same location on the destination computer as it was on the source computer.
segment.target: To successfully migrate the settings of ICQ Pro, you must install ICQ Pro in the same location on the destination computer as it was on the source computer.

segment.source: Otherwise, after you run the LoadState tool, the application will not start.
segment.target: Otherwise, after you run the LoadState tool, the application will not start.

segment.source: You change the default installation location on 32-bit destination computers.
segment.target: You change the default installation location on 32-bit destination computers.

segment.source: You attempt to migrate from a 32-bit computer to a 64-bit computer.
segment.target: You attempt to migrate from a 32-bit computer to a 64-bit computer.

segment.source: This is because the ICQ Pro default installation directory is different on the two types of computers.
segment.target: This is because the ICQ Pro default installation directory is different on the two types of computers.

segment.source: When you install ICQ Pro on a 32-bit computer, the default location is "C:Program Files...".
segment.target: When you install ICQ Pro on a 32-bit computer, the default location is "C:Program Files...".

segment.source: The ICQ Pro default installation directory on an x64-based computer, however, is “C:Program Files (x86)...”.
segment.target: The ICQ Pro default installation directory on an x64-based computer, however, is “C:Program Files (x86)...”.

segment.source: USMT does not migrate the following operating-system settings.
segment.target: USMT does not migrate the following operating-system settings.

segment.source: Local printers, hardware-related settings, drivers, passwords, application binary files, synchronization files, DLL files, or other executable files.
segment.target: Local printers, hardware-related settings, drivers, passwords, application binary files, synchronization files, DLL files, or other executable files.

segment.source: After migration, you must manually re-share any folders that were shared on the source computer.
segment.target: After migration, you must manually re-share any folders that were shared on the source computer.

segment.source: Files and settings migrating between operating systems with different languages.
segment.target: Files and settings migrating between operating systems with different languages.

segment.source: The operating system of the source computer must match the language of the operating system on the destination computer.
segment.target: The operating system of the source computer must match the language of the operating system on the destination computer.

segment.source: Customized icons for shortcuts may not migrate.
segment.target: Customized icons for shortcuts may not migrate.

segment.source: Taskbar settings, when the source computer is running Windows XP.
segment.target: Taskbar settings, when the source computer is running Windows XP.

segment.source: You should also note the following:
segment.target: You should also note the following:

segment.source: You should run USMT from an account with administrative credentials.
segment.target: You should run USMT from an account with administrative credentials.

segment.source: Otherwise, some data will not migrate.
segment.target: Otherwise, some data will not migrate.

segment.source: When running the ScanState and LoadState tools you must run the tools in Administrator mode from an account with administrative credentials.
segment.target: When running the ScanState and LoadState tools you must run the tools in Administrator mode from an account with administrative credentials.

segment.source: If you do not run USMT in Administrator mode, only the user profile that is logged on will be included in the migration.
segment.target: If you do not run USMT in Administrator mode, only the user profile that is logged on will be included in the migration.

segment.source: In addition, you must run the ScanState tool on Windows XP from an account with administrative credentials.
segment.target: In addition, you must run the ScanState tool on Windows XP from an account with administrative credentials.

segment.source: Otherwise, some operating-system settings will not migrate.
segment.target: Otherwise, some operating-system settings will not migrate.

segment.source: To run in Administrator mode, click Start, click All Programs, click Accessories, right-click Command Prompt, and then click Run as administrator.
segment.target: To run in Administrator mode, click Start, click All Programs, click Accessories, right-click Command Prompt, and then click Run as administrator.

segment.source: You can use the /localonly option to exclude the data from removable drives and network drives mapped on the source computer.
segment.target: You can use the /localonly option to exclude the data from removable drives and network drives mapped on the source computer.

segment.source: For more information about what is excluded when you specify /localonly, see ScanState Syntax.
segment.target: For more information about what is excluded when you specify /localonly, see ScanState Syntax.
